text-decoration: none;\">September 30, 2016 at 7:01 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_56MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nLike you said, capillaries of brain are much finer<br />\n<br />\nWill the Valsalva maneuver damage them ?<br />\n<br />\nI used to do that as a kid as my face used to turn red.</div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>FIRST WATCH THE CRIMINAL VIDEO IN THE LINK BELOW--&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>IT IS NOT A SAFE WAY TO GET A HIGH&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>IT IS ASKING YOU TO DIE .</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%;\"><a href=\"https://vimeo.com/19002333\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">https://vimeo.com/19002333</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vVi5m2e4Xmw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vVi5m2e4Xmw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">IF SRI SRI RAVISHANKAR GOES TO SOUTH AMERICA\nHE WILL BE ARRESTED AND JAILED .. &nbsp; MY OFFICERS HAVE INFORMED ME .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">HE WILL DIE IN A &nbsp;JAIL, &nbsp; CHARGED WITH MAN\nSLAUGHTER&nbsp;&nbsp; . .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZPEmChqqlZI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZPEmChqqlZI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">VALSALVA MANOEVRE &nbsp;INVOLVES THE VAGUS NERVE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">MY WIFE ATTENDED SRI SRI RAVISHANKARs ART OF\nLIVING COURSE ON MY INSTRUCTIONS<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">I TOLD HER TO DO EXACTLY WHAT THE COURSE\nTEACHER ( A WOMAN ) TOLD HER --NOTHING MORE NOTHING LESS<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">I WARNED HER --AS SOON AS HER BRAIN CELLS\nSTARTS GETTING FRIED , SHE WILL FEEL HER BODY EXTREMITIES TINGLING FIRST AND\nTHEN VIBRATING LIKE MAD &nbsp;. .&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">SHE FELT IT SO MUCH , THAT SHE HAD TO TUCK\nHER ARMS AND FEET WITHIN HER BODY. &nbsp; SHE KNEW WHAT WAS COMING -- FOR I HAD TOLD HER ABOUT CARPOPEDAL SPASMS .</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></b></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN HAVE DIED DUE TO THE\nVIDEO ABOVE-- IT IS DANGEROUS--&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">IT IS DANGEROUS TO INDUCE HYNOCAPNIA &nbsp;ON YOURSELF BY\nHYPERVENTILATION<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: lime; color: red; font-family: &quot;calibri&quot; , sans-serif; line-height: 115%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_31.html\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_31.html</span></a></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Valsalva &nbsp;manoeuvre is performed by moderately forceful\nattempted exhalation against a closed airway, usually done by closing one's\nmouth, pinching one's nose shut\u2014 people use this to pop their ears when an\naircraft lands<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In diving, the Valsalva\nmaneuver is often used on descent to equalise the pressure in the middle ear to\nthe ambient pressure. If the Valsalva maneuver is conducted during ascent,\nresidual air overpressure in the middle-ear can potentially be released through\nthe Eustachian tubes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the videos above the\nchildren by hyperventilation and immediate Valsalva ( self induced hypocapnia )\n&nbsp;intentionally cutting off oxygen to the\nbrain with the goal of inducing temporary loss of consciousness and euphoria. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the video the\nchildren do SO HUM type hyperventilation (forced overbreathing) until symptoms\nof hypocapnia such as tingling, light-headedness or dizziness are felt,\nfollowed by a Valsalva breath-hold. The vagus nerve is stimulated<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation leads\nto an excessive elimination of carbon dioxide (CO2) whereas no significant\nadditional amounts of oxygen can be stocked in the body.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As only carbon dioxide\nis responsible for the breathing stimulus, after hyperventilation, breath can\nbe held longer until cerebral hypoxia occurs.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The blood also becomes abnormally\nalkaline as a result of the excessive elimination of carbon dioxide; this\nsubsequent rise in blood pH is termed alkalosis. Alkalosis interferes with\nnormal oxygen utilization by the brain.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The symptoms of alkalosis are\nneuromuscular irritability, muscular spasms, tingling and numbness of the\nextremities and around the mouth, and a dizziness, or giddiness, often\ninterpreted as a sense of euphoria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">In the body alkalosis\ngenerally induces vasodilatation (widening of the blood vessels) but in the\nbrain alone it causes vasoconstriction (narrowing of the blood vessels).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">This\nvasoconstriction appears to be made even worse by a sudden increase in blood\npressure caused by squeezing or holding the breath \"hard\".&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nalkalosis-induced euphoria can be followed rapidly by hypoxia-induced unconsciousness.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sequence of events leading to unconsciousness from\nhyperventilation is as follows----<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Decrease in partial\npressure of alveolar CO2.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Decrease in partial\npressure of arterial CO2.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Increase in blood pH,\n(respiratory alkalosis).<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Vasoconstriction of\nblood vessels supplying brain.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Pooling of the blood\npresent in the brain at the time.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Brain rapidly uses up\noxygen (O2) available in the pooled blood.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>O2 concentration in the\nbrain drops.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Unconsciousness from\nhypoxia of cerebral tissue.</i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Because the brain\ncannot store reserves of oxygen and, unlike other organs, has an exceedingly\nlow tolerance of oxygen deprivation, it is highly vulnerable if\nvasoconstriction is not reversed.&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Normally, if the brain is hypoxic, autonomous\nsystems in the body divert blood to the brain at the expense of other organs;\nbecause the brain is vasoconstricted this mechanism is not available.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vasoconstriction\nis only reversed by the build-up of carbon dioxide in the blood through\nsuspension of breathing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hypocapnia causes\ncerebral vasoconstriction, leading to cerebral hypoxia and this can cause\ntransient dizziness, visual disturbances, and anxiety.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low partial pressure\nof carbon dioxide in the blood also causes alkalosis (because CO2 is acidic in\nsolution), leading to lowered plasma calcium ions and increased nerve and\nmuscle excitability.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This explains the other common symptoms of hyperventilation\n\u2014pins and needles, muscle cramps and tetany in the extremities, especially\nhands and feet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the brain stem\nregulates breathing by monitoring the level of blood CO2, hypocapnia can\nsuppress breathing to the point of blackout from cerebral hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Hypocapnia reduces the\noxygen levels available to the brain due to the elevated affinity of oxygen to\nhemoglobin (Bohr effect) hence highly increasing the chances of blackout.</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-size: large;\"><b>Hypocapnia is a state\nof reduced carbon dioxide in the blood.&nbsp;</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-size: large;\"><b>Hypocapnia usually results from deep or\nrapid breathing, known as hyperventilation.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low partial pressure\nof carbon dioxide in the blood also causes alkalosis (because CO2 is acidic in\nsolution), leading to lowered plasma calcium ions and increased nerve and\nmuscle excitability.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This explains the other common symptoms of\nhyperventilation \u2014pins and needles, muscle cramps and tetany in the\nextremities, especially hands and feet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the brain stem\nregulates breathing by monitoring the level of blood CO2, hypocapnia can\nsuppress breathing to the point of blackout from cerebral hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Note : Lung air\npressure is increased by holding the breath \"hard\" or \"bearing\ndown\" -tightening the diaphragm as in a forced exhalation while allowing\nno air to escape.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>Hyperventilation leads\nto an excessive elimination of carbon dioxide (CO2) with&nbsp; no significant additional amounts of oxygen\nstored in the body. </b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As only carbon dioxide\nis responsible for the breathing stimulus, after hyperventilation, breath can\nbe held longer until cerebral hypoxia occurs. The blood becomes &nbsp;abnormally alkaline as a result of the&nbsp; excessive elimination of carbon dioxide; this\n&nbsp;subsequent rise in blood pH is termed\nalkalosis. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alkalosis interferes\nwith normal oxygen utilization by the brain. The symptoms of &nbsp;alkalosis are neuromuscular irritability,\nmuscular spasms, tingling and numbness of the &nbsp;extremities and around the mouth, and a\ndizziness, or giddiness, often interpreted as a sense of euphoria.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-93Mi1EmTQb0/V-6kIyUj4YI/AAAAAAABMOM/OYb_5bbYesg2fCV9qhGMdzz8LqOHPT6dQCLcB/s1600/brain-oxfygen-effMMects-htypocapnia-hyperventilation.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"615\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-93Mi1EmTQb0/V-6kIyUj4YI/AAAAAAABMOM/OYb_5bbYesg2fCV9qhGMdzz8LqOHPT6dQCLcB/s640/brain-oxfygen-effMMects-htypocapnia-hyperventilation.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">VEDIC YOGA ALLOWS ONLY\nDEEP DIAPHRAGMATIC BREATHING\u2014NOT HYPERVENTILATION</span> OF SO HUM \u2013 SUDARSHAN KRIYA&nbsp;OF SRI SRI RAVISHANKAR &nbsp;. . . .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THIS IS CRIMINAL PATENTED YOGA&nbsp; TO MAKE MANDHA BUDDHIS OUT OF YOUNG INDIAN CHILDREN . .&nbsp;.</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/zCLDHEtL4F8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/zCLDHEtL4F8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Again, hypocapnia is a state\nof reduced carbon dioxide in the blood due to hyperventilation. </b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation describes\nexcessive ventilation of the lungs, beyond what is required to achieve normal\narterial blood gases.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Hyperventilation, or over-breathing, does not add oxygen\nto arterial blood.&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is because under normal physiological states arterial\nblood is close to saturation with respect to oxygen and is simply not able to\nabsorb more.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation has little\neffect on arterial pO2 and almost no effect on oxygen saturation which is\nnearly 100% under normal circumstances. &nbsp; Its main effect is to lower pCO2 and\nproduce a respiratory alkalosis. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If we breathe within\nnormal parameters this mechanism works very well to deliver oxygen to brain and\nbody tissues. &nbsp;By contrast, over-breathing (i.e breathing more than the\nphysiological norm) can upset this delicate balance thereby reducing oxygen\ndelivery to cells.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Hyperventilation does\nnot only reduce the total cerebral blood flow, but also changes the\ndistribution of blood flow within the brain. &nbsp;</span></b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Blood\nflow to the frontal, occipital, and parieto-occipital cortex, as well as the\nhippocampus is reduced relative to other areas of the brain within seconds to\nminutes of commencing hyperventilation.</span></b><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;georgia&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: x-large;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;georgia&quot; , &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: x-large;\"><b><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Sri Sri Ravishankar\ndoes NOT have a technical brain .</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">He has\nPATENTED this Sudharshan Kriya ( SO HUM hyperventilation </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">) by trying to rehash Yogic pranayama exercises\nlike Bhastrika and Kapalabhati.</span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">YOGA HAS SHUNNED\nHYPERVENTILATION , AND HAS USED BHASTRIKA PRANAYAMA ONLY TO SHIFT THE DOMINANT\nNOSTRIL ( IDA / PINGALA )&nbsp; FOR A FEW\nSECONDS.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Never join a FAKE yoga\nclass where they teach PATENTED hyperventilation and this is against the tenets\nand basic principle of&nbsp; ancient Yoga.&nbsp; &nbsp;6000\nyear old Ayurveda shuns hyperventilation and chest breathing.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I am from Kerala, the\nland of Ayurveda.&nbsp; Brain diseases (or\ndisorders of the central nervous system - CNS) are possible only in conditions\nof chronic hyperventilation, chest breathing and mouth breathing.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanatana Dharma does\nNOT allow you to create HARMFUL YOGA , patent it , make moolah and live like\nkings--and run down the wooden ramp through a gaping crowd ,like a MESSIAH&nbsp; ( all the while hiding the bouncing\ngangantuan paunch with a white shawl )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation leads\nto \"spontaneous and asynchronous firing of neurons\".&nbsp; &nbsp;This\nis why white people have panic attacks, seizures, sleeping problems, anxiety\nbreathing disorders, depression, bipolar disorder, senile dementia, Parkinson,\nAlzheimer disease, anxiety, panic phobia, depression, migraine, and idiopathic\nseizures.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation and\nabnormal electrical signals in the brain take place simultaneously.&nbsp; Chest breathing results in drastic reduction\nof blood oxygenation since lower parts of the lungs get more than 7&nbsp; times richer blood supply.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adverse&nbsp;\nbiochemical and immune effects of mouth/ chest breathing are too numerous\nand too shocking to even expound .&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"color: purple; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Our diaphragm flattens when we are stressed\nand we begin to breathe shallowly and faster , which raises our stress level\neven more.&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Changing your breathing pattern is an important step in reducing\nstress.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>When we do deep diaphragmatic breathing, our stress levels will\ndecrease because it allows more oxygen to flow through the body. &nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yogic breathing puts us in a parasympathetic\n(calm and relaxed) from a sympathetic (fight or flight) nervous system.&nbsp; It optimizes the carbon dioxide (CO2) and\noxygen (O2) exchange in the lungs to give greater space in the thoracic cavity\nduring inhalation.&nbsp; A better CO2/O2\nexchange also allows for higher oxygen saturation in our blood.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The diaphragm\nis also an important muscle in core stabilization, working with internal and\nexternal obliques, the quadratus lumborum, transverse abdominis and pelvic\nfloor.&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yoga does NOT allow you\nto eat like a glutton. Having an overfull stomach causes you to do chest\nbreathing.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">MORBIDLY OBESE PEOPLE CAN\nREDUCE WEIGHT BY YOGIC BREATHING--FAT GOES OUT AS SHIT&nbsp; !&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Deep diaphragmatic breathing stimulates the\ncleansing work of the lymph system by creating a negative pressure pulling the\nlymph through the lymph system. This increases the rate of elimination of\ntoxins from visceral organs by more than 16 TIMES..&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lymph nodes connected to the stomach,\nkidneys, liver, pancreas, spleen, large and small colons, and other vital\norgans are located just under the diaphragm - over 62% of all lymph nodes in\ntotal!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">When we breathe more\nair, by hyperventilation, we get less oxygen in body cells.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-size: large;\">In fact, the slower\nyour automatic breathing pattern at rest (down to only 3 breaths/min), the\nlarger the amount of oxygen delivered to cells. </span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Hyperventilation occurs\nwhen the rate and quantity of alveolar ventilation of carbon dioxide exceeds\nthe body's production of carbon dioxide. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Hyperventilation can be voluntary or\ninvoluntary.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-size: large;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">When alveolar ventilation\nis excessive, more carbon dioxide will be removed from the blood stream than\nthe body can produce. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">This causes the\nconcentration of carbon dioxide in the blood stream to fall and produces a\nstate known as hypocapnia. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The body\nnormally attempts to compensate for this metabolically. If excess ventilation\ncannot be compensated metabolically, it will lead to a rise in blood pH. This\nrise in blood pH is known as respiratory alkalosis.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\">When hyperventilation leads\nto respiratory alkalosis, it may cause a number of physical symptoms:\ndizziness, tingling in the lips, hands or feet, headache, weakness, fainting\nand seizures. In extreme cases it can cause </span><span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red; font-size: large;\">carpopedal spasms </span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\">(flapping and\ncontraction of the hands and feet) .</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">In normal breathing, both the depth and\nfrequency of breaths are varied by the neural (or nervous) system, primarily in\norder to maintain normal amounts of carbon dioxide but also to supply\nappropriate levels of oxygen to the body's tissues.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">This is mainly achieved by\nmeasuring the carbon dioxide content of the blood; normally, a high carbon\ndioxide concentration signals a low oxygen concentration, as we breathe in\noxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide at the same time, and the body's cells\nuse oxygen to burn fuel molecules, making carbon dioxide as a by-product.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Normal minute ventilation is generally 5\u20138 liters of air per minute at rest for\na 70 kg man. If carbon dioxide levels are high, the body assumes that oxygen\nlevels are low, and accordingly, the brain's blood vessels dilate to assure\nsufficient blood flow and supply of oxygen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Conversely, low carbon dioxide\nlevels cause the brain's blood vessels to constrict, resulting in reduced blood\nflow to the brain and lightheadedness. The gases in the alveoli of the lungs\nare nearly in equilibrium with the gases in the blood.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Normally, less than 10%\nof the gas in the alveoli is replaced with each breath taken. Deeper or quicker\nbreaths as in hyperventilation exchange more of the alveolar gas with ambient\nair and have the net effect of expelling more carbon dioxide from the body,\nsince the carbon dioxide concentration in normal air is very low.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The resulting\nlow concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood is known as hypocapnia. Since\ncarbon dioxide is carried as bicarbonate in the blood, the loss of carbon\ndioxide will drive bicarbonate to combine with hydrogen ions (protons) to form\nmore carbon dioxide.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The loss of hydrogen ions results in the blood becoming\nalkaline, i.e. the blood pH value rises. This is known as a respiratory\nalkalosis. This alkalization of the blood causes vessels to constrict\n(vasoconstriction).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The high pH value resulting from hyperventilation also\nreduces the level of available calcium (hypocalcemia), which affects the nerves\nand muscles, causing constriction of blood vessels and tingling.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">This occurs\nbecause alkalization of the plasma proteins (mainly albumin) increases their\ncalcium binding affinity, thereby reducing free ionized calcium levels in the\nblood.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Therefore, low levels of carbon dioxide can cause tetany by altering the\nalbumin binding of calcium such that the ionised (physiologically influencing)\nfraction of calcium is reduced.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Therefore, there are two main mechanisms that\ncontribute to the cerebral vasoconstriction that is responsible for the\nlightheadedness, paresthesia, and fainting often seen with hyperventilation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Stupid people think that this most damaging thing is a good thingy.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">One mechanism is that low carbon dioxide\n(hypocapnia) causes increased blood pH level (respiratory alkalosis), causing\nblood vessels to constrict.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The other mechanism is that the alkalosis causes\ndecreased freely ionized blood calcium, thereby causing cell membrane\ninstability and subsequent vasoconstriction and paresthesia.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anesthetic drug dosages\ncan be reduced by mechanically hyperventilating patients under general\nanesthesia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patients under anesthesia\nwere noted to sweat in a cold surgical theatre in the past which set surgeons\n/&nbsp; anesthesiologist wondering .&nbsp; This effect is but one of the several\nfascinating effects of hyperventilation on the human body.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">WW2 fighter pilots\nfound out clouding of consciousness and unconsciousness became increasingly\nlikely when the carbon dioxide pressure fell below 30 mmHg&nbsp; -- that all people developed neurological\nsymptoms due to hyperventilation at a carbon dioxide pressure of 20 mmHg .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">People with\nhyperventilation commonly describe symptoms such as disturbed mentation,\nimpaired concentration, poor memory, and hallucinations. Feelings of\ndepersonalization are also common, where hyperventilating persons describe\nsensations of unreality, or feeling everything is confused and dream-like.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>Hallucinating effects have been used by FAKE gurus to make an ass out of\ndevotees..</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Visual experiences such\nas blurred vision, tunnel vision, flashing lights, and seeing double also\noccur).&nbsp; Hyperventilation can cause brain\ndeath.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan;\">Hyperventilation\nreduces the cerebral blood flow by causing constriction [narrowing] of the\narteries supplying the brain with blood</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">Cerebral blood flow is\ndirectly related to the carbon dioxide pressure in the blood, and inversely\nrelated to the pH of the blood flowing through the arteries going to the brain\n. &nbsp;&nbsp;In other words, the lower the carbon\ndioxide pressure in the blood, the lower the cerebral blood flow&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All people develop neurological\nmanifestations due to hyperventilation below an arterial carbon dioxide\npressure of 20 mmHg.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Extreme levels of\nhyperventilation, where the carbon dioxide pressure drops below 25-30 mmHg\ncause the cerebral blood flow to drop below 40 ml/100 gm/min, a level below\nwhich increasingly more people develop manifestations of cerebral hypoxia<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Binding of oxygen with\nhemoglobin provides further evidence that hyperventilation may well cause brain\ntissue hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Blood is a transport\nfluid. It transports oxygen, electrolytes, proteins, hormones, fats and sugars\nto tissues, and removes waste products of metabolism, hormones, products of\nmetabolisms, etc away from tissues. Oxygen is transported by blood from the\nlungs where it enters the body. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However oxygen is very\npoorly soluble in blood, and blood contains negligible amounts of dissolved\noxygen. Practically all oxygen in blood is chemically bound to hemoglobin\ninside red blood cells. But the chemical binding of oxygen with hemoglobin is\ndirectly affected by the acidity and alkalinity of blood (i.e. the pH of\nblood).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Hyperventilation causes\nloss of carbon dioxide from the body, causing the pH of blood to increase and\nbecome more alkaline. When blood is more alkaline, hemoglobin binds more\ntightly with oxygen.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Oxygen bound to\nhemoglobin within red blood cells does nothing, because binding of oxygen to\nhemoglobin within red blood cells is no more than the body's method of\ntransporting oxygen to the capillaries within the tissues of the body.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Within\nthe capillaries of the tissues of the body, the chemical bond between oxygen\nand hemoglobin is weak enough to allow oxygen to leave the blood and diffuse\ninto the cells surrounding the capillaries, so providing oxygen for the vital,\nenergy-generating chemical processes within the cells forming the tissues of\nthe body. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But when\nhyperventilation causes oxygen to bind more tightly to hemoglobin, less oxygen\nis released to diffuse into the tissues surrounding the capillaries.&nbsp; Hyperventilation can cause less oxygen to\nenter the tissues of the body from the capillaries, so resulting in hypoxia of\nthe cells outside the blood vessels, even though the blood contains more than\nsufficient oxygen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperventilation has\nprofound effects on the transport and delivery of oxygen to the tissues of the\nbody. &nbsp;Again, hyperventilation reduces the cerebral blood flow, and to make matters\nworse, hyperventilation also causes oxygen to bind more tightly with\nhemoglobin. Both factors combine to reduce the availability of oxygen to the\ntissues of the brain, and can even cause cerebral hypoxia.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The tragic fatal\neffects of relative hyperventilation in humans with severe chronic obstructive\nairway disease, also reveals that hyperventilation in humans can result in\ncerebral hypoxia severe enough to cause actual brain damage and brain death .\nHyperventilation has</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">been implicated as\none of the potential causes of postoperative cognitive dysfunction.</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fancy term for\nbreath-holding is Valsalva.&nbsp; Taking its\nname from 17th Century Italian Anatomist, Anton Maria Valsalva, the Valsalva\nManeuver (or simply, Valsalva) occurs when we attempt to forcibly exhale while\nkeeping the mouth and nose closed. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The abdominal muscles\ntighten up, which then squeezes the intestines and organs in the abdominal\ncavity so that they press upward against the diaphragm.&nbsp; The diaphragm then bulges upward, compressing\nthe chest cavity.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Certain chest muscles\nalso tighten to bring the rib cage down, which compresses the chest cavity even\nmore.&nbsp; Concurrently, the larynx closes\ntightly around the upper airway to keep the air in the lungs from escaping. The\nmore the abdominal muscles squeeze, the greater the air pressure becomes in the\nlungs, the tighter the larynx closes, magnifying the Valsalva effect<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Elderly people are\ncommonly found dead of a stroke on the commode because of increased blood\npressure from Valsalva, while straining during constipation. It causes a rise\nin blood pressure followed by a sharp drop and then a second sharp rise in\nblood pressure.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This may be dangerous in people with heart disease. This is\nwithout hyperventilation.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8h3UKiWAXyA/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/8h3UKiWAXyA?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">My wife just reminded\nme yesterday.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
